intro: Silene cattariniana, commonly known as the Cattarinian catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, pinkish-purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands or along stream banks. It has narrow, linear leaves and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Silene cattariniana is a rare species, listed as endangered in some states due to habitat loss and fragmentation.
